choices.C: Configure static routes for remote subnets.
choices.A: Configure Reverse Route Injection on the dynamic crypto map.
choices.D: Configure snapshot routing with EIGRP to send out of band routing updates.
choices.B: Configure a default route with the tunneled keyword on all branch routers.

questions.question_text: A company is setting up a dynamic crypto map on the Cisco ASA at the headquarters to accept connections from the branch offices. There will be no IP subnet overlap between the branch offices, but the engineer does not know which encryption domains will be requested by the branch offices. Additionally, the company security policy states that routing protocol traffic should not leave the HQ network. Which solution should be used to route traffic back to the branches from the Cisco ASA with minimal administrative effort?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Cause MSS is relevant only for TCP traffic. https://www.networkworld.com/article/2224654/mtu-size-issues.html

Selected Answer: C
tcp adjust-mss is for tcp traffic only. TFTP is UDP. The only answer can be C.

choices.A: Set the tunnel IP MTU to 1500.
choices.B: Set the tunnel tcp adjust-mss to 1460.
choices.C: Set the tunnel IP MTU to 1400.
choices.D: Set the tunnel tcp adjust-mss to 1360.

questions.question_text: A network engineer is implementing a FlexVPN tunnel between two Cisco IOS routers. The FlexVPN tunnels will terminate on encrypted traffic on an interface configured with an IP MTU of 1500, and the company has a security policy to drop fragmented traffic coming into or leaving the network. The tunnel will be used to transfer TFTP data between users and internal servers. When the TFTP traffic is not traversing a VPN, it can have a maximum IP packet size of 1500. Assuming the encrypted payload will add 90 bytes, which configuration allows TFTP traffic to traverse the FlexVPN tunnel without being dropped?

choices.E: ECC lags in performance when compared with RSA.
choices.C: ECC cannot have the same security as RSA, even with an increased key size.
choices.A: Key generation in ECC is slower and more CPU intensive than RSA.
choices.B: ECC can have the same security as RSA but with a shorter key size.
choices.D: Key generation in ECC is faster and less CPU intensive than RSA.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct

questions.question_text: What are two differences between ECC and RSA? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: FlexVPN only supports the Internet Key Exchange version 2 (IKEv2) protocol. IKEv2 is the default protocol used in FlexVPN, and it is used for authentication and key exchange between the FlexVPN client and server

questions.question_text: Which configuration construct must be used in a FlexVPN tunnel?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. R1: Key Server – Customer 1 CEs: Group Members

Explanation:
In a GETVPN (Group Encrypted Transport VPN) deployment:

The Key Server (KS) is responsible for distributing keys and security policies to all Group Members (GMs).

GMs are routers participating in GETVPN and perform the actual encryption/decryption.

Since GETVPN is typically used for encryption between CE routers (Customer Edge) and does not rely on MPLS core (PE routers) for encryption, the Key Server is usually located at a central site router like R1.

In this scenario:

R1 is acting as the central Key Server.

Customer 1 CE1 and Customer 1 CE2 will act as Group Members to secure their traffic using GETVPN.

Selected Answer: A
GETVPN does not work in NAT environments.

Selected Answer: D
both Customer 1 and Customer 2 CEs need to be Group Members. 
GETVPN not supporting NAT, answer D is the only one taking both Customers CEs in to account.

Selected Answer: A
GetVPN does not work behind NAT

choices.B: Customer 1 CE1: Key Server – R1 and Customer 1 CE2: Group Members
choices.A: PE3: Key Server – Customer 2 CEs: Group Members
choices.C: R1: Key Server – Customer 1 CEs: Group Members
choices.D: PE3: Key Server – all CEs: Group Members
